results.title: Feelings. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Justin Shortal, Cate Fyffe, CVV Productions and Environment Audio Visuals
results.brief_description: A series of vignettes is presented each of which focuses on one of the following feelings: anger; jealousy; rejection and loneliness. The dramatised situations are usually open-ended thus providing a stimulus for discussion. High school students are used to play the roles. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Feelings. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Justin Shortal, Cate Fyffe, CVV Productions and Environment Audio Visuals
results.brief_description: Presents seven separate incidents each with its own title and discussion questions: Smoking and drinking; Adolescents joining in with family activities; Cheating in exams; Aspirations; Losing a loved pet; Friendship and trust; Infatuation and embarrassment. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Federation
results.creator_credit: Ian Munro, Anna Grieve and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The story of Federation is an epic tale of Australia. This three part journey to nationhood looks at the land, the people, and the nation, recounting stories of the founding fathers and of the people from six separate colonies during the decades preceding Federation. The story depicts a struggle to create an Australian democracy which occurred as a result of the federation of Australian colonies in 1901. It does not glorify events or characters or avoid the more sensitive or troublesome facts of our past. It faces the hard issues of who was excluded from the rights and privileges of Australian citizenship, and thus includes the voices of women and Indigenous people who were largely ignored at the time. The tale is one of victory and loss, success, resistance and debate, and of the struggle not just to make an Australian nation, but to create a democracy. Written by Sue Castrique and narrated by John Doyle (Roy Slaven). The story is presented in 3 episodes: The Land, The People, The Nation, although each episode can stand alone.

results.title: Feathers and Fools
results.brief_description: Based on a short story by Mem Fox. This is a parable about two groups of birds - swans and peacocks - who are greatly afraid of their respective differences.

results.title: Fathers of pop
results.creator_credit: Julian Cooper, Rodney Wilson and Arts Council of Great Britain
results.brief_description: London in the 1950’s saw the beginnings of a ferment from which “the London Pop Scene” emerged in the sixties. Said to have begun with the Independent Group at the Institute of Contemporary Arts, one of its members at the time, Reyner Benham, reconstructs some of the events, attitudes and influences of the time and discusses with the survivors how it was then and how it looks now.

results.title: Fashion daze : Australian style on the catwalk 1910s-1970s
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Fashion daze is a glimpse of Australian womens’ fashion and style from the early 1910s to the 1970s. Focusing on fashion parades of lingerie, day wear, hats, leisure wear, evening wear and bridal gowns, styles from each decade are presented. Narrated by Lyn Mills.

results.title: Farrebique
results.creator_credit: Georges Rouquier, Ecran Francais and Films Etienne Lallier
results.brief_description: Farrebique is the first feature-length work for French documentary filmmaker Georges Rouqier. Filmed in 1944 and 45, the focus is on one year in the life of a rural French family, observing them through the seasons. The family, cousins of the director living in the farming community of Aveyron in South-central France, act out sequences that correspond to actual events unfurling in their lives. Ideas of modernisation are slowly introduced; the notion of installing electricity for example is debated heatedly among key family members whilst the manual labours of farming life are clearly displayed. A fine example of ‘cinema verite’, the cycle of the seasons is linked to the cycles of life — birth, death, renewal — providing a humanist view of nature and the intrinsic phases of rural life. Featuring beautiful time-lapse photography to display the coming of Spring, the film can be read as a paean to a bucolic life, observing the minutiae of nature as well as documenting the hardships of working the land. This fascinating work is highly regarded and won numerous awards including the FIPRESCI Prize at Cannes, 1946.
